title: The KGB's last French secrets in Soviet archives
summary: 'Cold War moles' (Part 1/5). Le Monde is devoting a series of historical investigations to the well-known but partly unexploited archives handed over in 1992 by an exceptional defector, Vasili Mitrokhin. These reveal the little-known extent of Soviet infiltration of France.

title: Las Vegas Tesla explosion: Suspect left note saying it was to be a wake-up call for country's ills
summary: The explosion caused minor injuries to seven people but virtually no damage to the hotel. The suspect may have been planning a more damaging attack but the steel-sided vehicle absorbed much of the force from the crudely built explosive.

title: Judge schedules Trump's sentencing in hush-money case for January 10, hints at no jail time
summary: Trump takes office on January 20 as the first former president to be convicted of a crime and the first convicted criminal to be elected to office. His conviction left him facing the possibility of punishment ranging from a fine or probation to up to four years in prison.

title: The French far right's slow re-alignment on Ukraine
summary: Jordan Bardella has turned away from the party's prior Russophilia. Yet he maintains a delicate balance between the two positions that coexist among the far right.

title: 'Brothers-in-insomnia': Bernard-Henri Lévy's night-time messages to President Macron
summary: In his new book Nuit blanche ('Sleepless Night'), the philosopher relates his Telegram conversations with another famous insomniac: his neighbor, Emmanuel Macron.

title: 'Wallace & Gromit: Vengeance Most Fowl' on Netflix: the successful return of a delightfully old-fashioned duo
summary: The sixth adventure of the Lancashire inventor and his beagle pits them against an old foe, the bandit penguin Feathers McGraw.

title: Israeli strikes kill at least 30 in Gaza as ceasefire talks set to resume
summary: Israeli airstrikes killed at least 30 people in Gaza, including children, overnight and into Friday, according to hospital and emergency response workers. The strikes came as health workers and the Israeli military exchanged conflicting claims over reported evacuation orders for two hospitals in the largely isolated northern part of the territory.

title: Montenegro pledges crackdown on illegal weapons after New Year's Day massacre
summary: According to the Small Arms Survey (SAS), a Swiss research program, there are approximately 245,000 firearms in circulation in Montenegro, a nation of just over 620,000 people.

title: US House re-elects Trump ally Mike Johnson in dramatic speaker vote
summary: Initially, three US House Republicans had not backed previous speaker Mike Johnson, pushing the voting to another round, but Johnson was able to secure victory after negotiations led two of the party rebels to switch their initial 'no' votes.

title: French and German foreign ministers in Syria for talks with leader Sharaa
summary: French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot and his German counterpart Annalena Baerbock arrived in Damascus on Friday for discussions on behalf of the European Union.

title: In Damascus, among the ruins of Qaboun, the ghost of community tensions
summary: The Syrian capital's Sunni-populated suburb was besieged and bombed for years by government forces, in the name of protecting adjacent neighborhoods inhabited by Alawites, the minority forming the Assad regime's backbone. Today, both communities claim they want to live in peace.

title: Biden rejects Nippon Steel's proposed deal to acquire US Steel
summary: President Joe Biden rejected the nearly $15 billion proposed deal, which he and President-elect Donald Trump had both expressed opposition to.

title: French police officers to face trial over death of man who said he was 'suffocating' during arrest
summary: Cédric Chouviat, 42, was tackled to the ground while wearing his motorbike helmet, and was found to have said 'I'm suffocating' nine times during his arrest in January 2020. Judges have found the officers' behavior 'inappropriate, negligent and imprudent.'

title: After attack, New Orleans wants to show there is no danger to tourism
summary: The FBI declared that the terrorist, a former US serviceman, had most likely acted alone. Fourteen people were killed and 35 injured.

title: French government now aims for public deficit of 5.4% of GDP in 2025
summary: Several tax measures planned for the 2025 budget will not see the light of day, rendering Michel Barnier's 5% deficit target obsolete. To compensate for these missing revenues, a VAT increase has been ruled out.

title: Olga de Amaral, Colombia's textile visionary, steps into the light at Fondation Cartier
summary: Featuring 80 works – most of which have never been shown in France – the Paris exhibition highlights the earth-shattering energy of the Colombian designer's woven creations.

title: Death of Liam Payne: Man arrested in Argentina for supplying drugs to One Direction star
summary: Argentine police arrested one of five men indicted in connection with British singer Liam Payne's death in Buenos Aires, who had allegedly supplied the One Direction member with cocaine, which prosecutors have said he had consumed before falling to his death.

title: South Korea: President Yoon Suk Yeol's arrest prevented by his security services and the military
summary: Investigators were thwarted in their attempt to arrest suspended President Yoon Suk Yeol on Friday. The dramatic confrontation, which pitted law enforcement against Yoon's bodyguards, stems from his failed attempt to impose martial law.

title: Taliban assault on women's rights reaches a new level in Afghanistan
summary: The Islamist fundamentalists in power are demanding that NGOs operating in the country get rid of their female staff. They are also ordering kitchen windows to be blocked to conceal their female occupants.

title: US injects $306m into bird flu fight as concerns mount
summary: The new funding will support national, state, and local preparedness and monitoring programs, as well as research into potential medical countermeasures against the H5N1 virus.

title: Algeria through Piere Bourdieu's lens, on display at Paris's Pompidou Center
summary: When he was called up to serve in Algeria, in 1955, the sociologist took almost 3,000 photos of the country: Pictures of everyday life, women, men and children, field labor, and much more.

title: French prison hostage situation over after inmate surrenders
summary: The prisoner, a convicted rapist, had taken four nurses and one prison guard hostage, using a handmade shank, and held them in the southern city of Arles' prison infimary for hours, before surrendering. No-one was hurt, according to authorities.

title: Press caricatures: 'A certain fear weighs on both cartoonists and newspaper editors'
summary: While press cartoons are in decline, they have also – especially since the January 7, 2015 attack on the magazine Charlie Hebdo – been the subject of hostile reactions and controversies, particularly online, explain historians Christian Delporte and Bruno Nassim Aboudrar in a joint interview.

title: Syria: Writer Yassin al-Haj Saleh's bittersweet return to Damascus
summary: After 11 years in exile, the writer, critic, and former political prisoner has returned to his homeland in search of answers about his wife, a human rights activist who was abducted in 2013.

title: In Paris, a portrait of Tokyo as a reborn city in the 1920s-1930s
summary: A hundred prints from the Edo-Tokyo Museum have made their way to the Maison de la culture du Japon à Paris to illustrate the metamorphosis of the vibrant capital of Japan after the 1923 earthquake.

title: In the Yarmouk refugee camp, the broken future of Syria's Palestinians
summary: This area on the southern outskirts of Damascus is the beating heart of the Palestinian diaspora. After being reduced to rubble during the civil war, only a few thousand inhabitants still live there.

title: South Korea: President resisting arrest sparks political crisis
summary: Yoon's lawyers decried Friday's arrest attempt as "unlawful and invalid", and vowed to take legal action.

title: Luke Littler, 17, crowned world darts champion amid festive atmosphere
summary: The young Englishman defeated his opponent, Dutchman Michael van Gerwen, in the final of the World Darts Championship in London on Friday evening, in a festive atmosphere filled with hops and stadium chants.

title: Euro falls to lowest level against dollar since 2022
summary: The European single currency continues to suffer from the divergent economic and monetary trajectories in the US and the eurozone.

title: In Montreal, 'peaceful mornings' at the museum for autistic children
summary: Every three months, the Montreal Science Centre sets aside a time slot with reduced capacity, dimmed lighting and lowered noise levels to welcome visitors with special needs.

title: 'We are entering a long period of relegation and neglect of the environmental issue'
summary: 2024, as well as leading to an unparalleled political crisis, also confirmed the near-total exit of environmental issues from the political agenda, writes Le Monde columnist Stéphane Foucart.

title: France and Germany will judge Syria's new regime 'by its actions'
summary: In Damascus, French and German foreign ministers Jean-Noël Barrot and Annalena Baerbock called for a 'peaceful and rigorous' transition with de facto Syrian leader Ahmed al-Sharaa.
